history.content:
Stat 153 is time series, which is not really related to ML or data science unless you want to work on ML problems specifically in this area.

Stat 140 is a probability theory course, somewhat more similar to EE126 but with a heavier emphasis on statistical concepts whereas EE126 considers more applications of the probability covered. Its easier than 126 mostly due to the fact that no probability background is assumed prior to 140 whereas 126 assumes you've taken CS70, so if probability is something that you feel especially weak on, consider one of these two.

Stat 135 is a very traditional statistics course, covers content like sampling, MLE estimation, hypothesis testing in various contexts, and the basics of linear regression. The early history of machine learning is essentially inspired by or coming from the content covered here, such as least squares/ridge regression as being the MLE/MAP estimate of parameters, LDA/QDA as an extension of hypothesis testing where the hypothesis are multivariate normal distribution etc. There is a lot of overlap with what you've seen or will see, so I wouldn't recommend considering this course unless you plan on taking something like Stat 210.

EDIT: After reading through the followup below, the points made here about 135 are less relevant since I took it with Professors Sahai and Listgarten rather than with Shewchuk which is a very different course. Check below for a more applicable perspective.

Stat 153 is time series, which is not really related to ML or data science unless you want to work on ML problems specifically in this area.

Stat 140 is a probability theory course, somewhat more similar to EE126 but with a heavier emphasis on statistical concepts whereas EE126 considers more applications of the probability covered. Its easier than 126 mostly due to the fact that no probability background is assumed prior to 140 whereas 126 assumes you've taken CS70, so if probability is something that you feel especially weak on, consider one of these two.

Stat 135 is a very traditional statistics course, covers content like sampling, MLE estimation, hypothesis testing in various contexts, and the basics of linear regression. The early history of machine learning is essentially inspired by or coming from the content covered here, such as least squares/ridge regression as being the MLE/MAP estimate of parameters, LDA/QDA as an extension of hypothesis testing where the hypothesis are multivariate normal distribution etc. There is a lot of overlap with what you've seen or will see, so I wouldn't recommend considering this course unless you plan on taking something like Stat 210.

children.subject: I took STAT 134 and STAT 135 before CS 189 this semester and found them quite useful.

@Student response - are the lecture notes discussing the statistical justification behind LDA/QDA etc available somewhere? I would love to read more about that now that you have brought the concept up. 

I enjoyed this semester of 189 but I also love statistical justification and wish I had a little bit more of that.

This is actually a pretty good exercise that I think you can figure out on your own. Try and derive LDA/QDA from the standard setup of hypothesis testing. My hint would be consider simple null vs simple alternative and binary classification.

I slightly disagree with the Student's Response regarding Stat135 - I had a different experience.

I took Stat135 in Fall 2018 with Lucas and 189 in Spring 2019 with Shewchuk, and only one lecture was spent discussing the statistical justification of some of the models we used, and it wasn't framed in the lingo of Stat135, so I don't think there is overlap. (Though this may not apply to the fall 189 profs who teach the course very differently)

Stat135 would be useful if you are interested in more statistical/mathematical justification for a lot of procedures you may have briefly encountered in other courses. 

You may have seen hypothesis testing in courses such as Data8 or Stat 2/20, but 135 discusses the justification behind why the testing works, in the context of the "power" of your test, a concept I have not seen in any other courses so far. 

189 heavily uses regression, but I felt the course did not justify the meaning/rigor behind the concept as much as 135 did. 

Stat135 will also teach you a handful of other practical skills such as z tests, t tests, f tests, ANOVA, test of homogeneity/independence, which are useful for your toolkit if you are interested to industry DS/ML. 

As a side note, if you've taken Data100, you might see a small overlap in a few concepts, but I actually enjoyed taking both Stat135 and Data100 because 135 gave me some mathematical justification for concepts such as hypothesis testing, permutation tests, regression, test for homogeneity, while in Data100 I got to code some practical applications of such concepts. 

tl;dr Stat135 will give you the why behind many concepts you have seen in other DS/ML courses

history.content: Which one of Stat 153/140/135 could be most useful for industry prospects relevant to DS/ML? For reference, I'll have taken Data 100 and will be taking CS 189 (with Shewchuk), EECS 127 and CS 182. Is there any ordering (in terms of usefulness/relevancy) to these 3 Stat courses? Are there any other Stat courses that I should consider? As an aside, I also absolutely hated theoretical courses like 70/170 but really liked Data 100, so I wouldn't want the course I take to be too theoretical. Thanks for any suggestions!
history.subject: Stat 135/153/140
